Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content:
<https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-drop/n-14-21.pdf>
points to
<https://www.fincen.gov/sites/default/files/shared/FIN-2013-G001.pdf>
In my readings, `Users of Virtual Currency` in the latter applies

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content:
`FinCEN doesn't matter here, IRS matters`
True, but what I'm saying is that the IRS's official stance is that the FinCEN doc is their basis and as such if FinCEN says it doesn't apply then the IRS can't say that it does if the IRS says that FinCEN is their guide (logically at least)

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content:
From the IRS:``` For a more comprehensive description of convertible virtual currencies to date, see Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) Guidance on the Application of FinCENâ€™s Regulations to Persons Administering, Exchanging, or Using Virtual Currencies (FIN-2013-G001, March 18, 2013).  ```

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content:
***

Any suggestions on how to monetise a site without compromising on privacy?

Do you know of any forms of ethical advertising/affiliates where people are not tracked with cookies across the web? 
I read that it's possible...in the sense that if they buy something from a totally unique link given to you, that's what tells the seller the buyer comes from you.

 The other common method is more effective, they usually use an ID that is in a cookie and it tracks visitors, but I don't want to use it - the whole site is focused on Privacy tech so it wouldn't be right.

My other idea is to integrate a form of crypto exchange, maybe something like what sideshift.ai offer to their partners

Would like to also make a utility coin with optional Z-addresses that members can use to pay for premium listings/special features and receive a discount if they use it.

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: optional privacy is basically no privacy at all

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: @D2D privacyalternatives.com

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: Even the way Hush and Verus do it?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: USSA will be running nodes for all the major coins, ip sniffing and detecting what node creates the transaction

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: staying private against a state level actor becomes quite difficult

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you would need something like ARRR

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: HUSH and VRSC will achieve corporate level privacy, but surrounded by taddr and all entry/exit to the chain monitored.... maybe its possible to stay private, but maybe not against a full scale surveillance state

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: Yes also from what I've been reading, ARRR is the only true privacy coin

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: Isn't there a risk they might ban coins with z-only addresses?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: many things are banned, but if it is something people really need, it survives

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: atomicDEX doesnt need any approvals, it is in a regulatory safe-harbor according to recent guidance

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think ussa tried to ban many things, but the only bans that worked were things that were centralized in nature where they could exert control on a small group of people

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: But why did Hush and VRSC choose optional z-addresses instead of z-only addresses?

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: And KMD doesn't have z-address anymore now

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: It's good to hear that atomicDEX is in a regulatory safe-harbor

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: going zaddr only means you cant really do anything else that transactions and store of value

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and even simple things like exchange integration become major ordeals and mobile is maybe not even possible without great contortions

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: PIRATE is the ultimate in privacy, but that is the only thing it can do

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe in the landscape of thousands of coins that cant do anything else either, PIRATE is their equal in functionality, but the next wave of alt season we will see many alts with enhanced capabilities and the vanilla forks that are not already firmly established wont have any chance

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content:
Yes that's what I thought and why I suggested making a z-optional coin if I do create one to go with the website.
ARRR already does full privacy very well

Author: hastrup#8742
Content: @D2D privacyalternatives.com one of the the biggest no no's I have about brave its chromium based hence its a Google product not directly but indirectly. I cannot for the life of me understand why they did not fork Firefox if brave what to be for privacy.

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: Thought brave was made by one of the guys from mozilla

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: assumed they forked ff

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content:
But from what I understand, there shouldn't be any link between the two, Google doesn't get any data from Chrome just because they are using the Chromium code.
I think technically by default Brave is the best for privacy (no telemetry, while Firefox has that). But if you understand the settings you can make Firefox super-private

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: Yes it was made by one of the guys at Mozilla, who was kicked out because they accused him of being homophobic

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brendan_Eich

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: he is also the creator of javascript

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: yes

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: About a year or so ago Brave had lots of bugs, but now it works very well, also the separate identities you can create, to browse different things and keep cookies/logins separate is great

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: I do like it

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: But I think his choice of asking for KYC to pay the Brave rewards (for watching ads) is an awful choice

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: I mean, a browser knows almost more about you than yourself

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: They should never ever ask for KYC

Author: hastrup#8742
Content: @D2D privacyalternatives.com but if you are using Chromium base you are also supporting chromium development hence you are supporting Google. Like you said you can make ff very secure and remove telemetry if you want. So why did brave now do that? Because a personal issue whit ff? Idk it's hard to find the perfect solution. I just want to not use Google related products that's why I'm using Firefox. (while sitting here using Android, fuck me right!)

Content: ahah...it's hard to stay away from Google, they are everywhere

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: I think there's a better ethos behind Mozilla and Firefox

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: But some sites seemed to always work better on Chromium than on Firefox for me

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content:
***
And there's no real alternative to Youtube yet

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content: The only thing you can do is use invidio.us - instead of the "youtube.com" part on the url,  you can put invidio.us and watch their videos without actually being on Youtube

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content:
For example if you want to watch this video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XplVo4LOlFY

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content:
You change the url and make it into:  https://invidio.us/watch?v=XplVo4LOlFY
And you can then watch it there without being on Youtube

Content:

Author: D2D privacyalternatives.com#5667
Content:
"Why not use the Blockchain and Cryptocurrency?
We're excited about about the new possibilities these technologies are creating, and we'd love to explore how they could help us achieve our goals. But just like we won't wait for self-driving cars to become ubiquitous before calling a Lyft, we're very practical about using existing services to solve problems right now. We can already get pretty far using well-established technologies already integrated with global systems. That said, we are actively exploring how to support cryptocurrency on the platform, so if you're interested in that, get in in touch."
